title: Fake It Till You Make It: Using Synthetic Data and Domain Knowledge for Improved Text-Based Learning for LGE Detection
author: Athira J Jacob (Siemens Healthineers), Puneet Sharma (Siemens Healthineers), Daniel Rueckert (Technical University of Munich), ..., Daniel Rueckert (Imperial College London)
relevance_why: The paper presents techniques for improving model performance in a specialized imaging domain, which could inspire methods applicable to audio signal processing where labeled data is scarce.
background: Detecting late gadolinium enhancement in cardiac MRI images involves identifying subtle signal changes, a task that can be challenging due to the necessity of precise clinical annotations.
contribution: This study introduces synthetic data augmentation and text-based training methods to enhance the detection of myocardial scarring from limited clinical data, achieving a balanced accuracy of 83%.
technical_comparison: Previous methods require large annotated datasets or substantial fine-tuning, often limited by domain-specific challenges. This work improves performance by utilizing synthetic images and text guidance without extensive retraining.
key_innovation: The innovative use of synthetic data generated from domain knowledge allows for effective training on a limited dataset, maintaining high performance without requiring full image-text pair datasets.
real_world_impact: This approach can facilitate more efficient and accessible methods for assessing cardiac conditions in clinical settings, which could lead to improved patient outcomes.
limitations: The model's reliance on clinical report quality and the generalizability of synthetic data created is not thoroughly evaluated.

new_terms.Late Gadolinium Enhancement (LGE): **Late Gadolinium Enhancement (LGE)** is a cardiac magnetic resonance imaging technique used to detect scarring of the heart muscle after the administration of gadolinium-based contrast agents.
